text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:
-The central bank has given up efforts to calm the economy, financial experts say. They fear the economy will overheat after the bank's cut in interest rates on Tuesday.
-Norway's second largest commercial bank Kreditkassen posted operating results of 1.4 billion crowns after the first nine months of 1996, up by 11.4 percent from the same-year ago period.

-Nordem, a new Norwegian troop of 90 different experts are ready for to take up positions for the United Nations' Human Rights division. Representatives from the group met U.N. Commissionaire Jose Ayalo Lasso in Geneva on Tuesday to sign an agreement of intent.

-Norsk Hydro and its partners will invest 60 billion crowns by 2000 in new projects in the North Sea. In addition to five platforms already operated by Hydro, the company plans to develop eight new installations.
-Salmon farmers are waiting for an European Union decision on minimum pricing. Regulation of salmon prices will cause losses for Norwegian farmers but will benefit their Scottish counterparts.
